thread.title: Calexit: Californians start campaigning to secede from the US - but they don't have Ukip's support
thread.title_full: Calexit: Californians start campaigning to secede from the US - but they don't have Ukip's support

author: Helena Horton
title: Calexit: Californians start campaigning to secede from the US - but they don't have Ukip's support
text:
News Calexit: Californians start campaigning to secede from the US - but they don't have Ukip's support A tower from the Golden Gate Bridge is seen over a blanket of fog Credit: AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez Helena Horton  23am 
H ard-working campaigners could be about to do for California what the Leave campaign did for the UK — but Ukip isn't supporting them. 
'Calexit' could be a reality ; in the wake of Donald Trump's election, Californians are fighting to secede from the US. 
On Thursday, California Secretary of State Alex Padilla cleared the proposed initiative to start collecting signatures. 
If enough signatures are collected, Calexit could be on the ballot in 2018. 
If this ballot gains the majority of voters, it would repeal clauses in the California Constitution stating that the state is an "inseparable part of the United States" and that the U.S. Constitution is the "supreme law of the land". Watch | Anti-Trump protest in California spills over onto 'freeway' 00:13 
T his would mean California could govern itself. 
Gawain Towler, Ukip's spokesperson, has said that although the party doesn't get involved in the affairs of other countries, he isn't enthusiastic about Calexit. 
He said the liberal agenda of many of those in LA skew the vote blue, when many in the state vote Republican, and therefore perhaps instead of seceding   section California into smaller states. 
Mr Towler told the Telegraph: "Other people in California would like to break it into smaller parts so it's not governed by West Coast fantasies. 
"A lot of California is red, but because LA is so big, it always goes blue. 
"I'm sure there are people on both sides of the debate but UKIP is not getting involved." Signature gathering starts today. We expect circulating title and summary from CA AG later this evening. https://t.co/qfB4MEHhFy — Yes California (@YesCalifornia) January 25, 2017 
Y es California, the campaigners for the proposal, have argued the state is culturally out of step with the rest of the US. 
California is the state with the most electoral college votes, with 55. 
"California loses [by] being a part of America culturally and financially," Marcus Ruiz Evans, one of the group's founders told the LA times. 
"It could be a nation all its own, everybody knows that. The only question is if they want to break off." 
61.5 per cent of Californians voted for Hillary Clinton and 31.5 pc did for Donald Trump. 
To qualify for the ballot, Yes California has to collect 585,407 valid signatures from registered voters over the next 180 days.
